I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed fantastic presenting skills, responding skills and critical thinking skills in taking this class. It allowed me to be academic about things I never thought would fall under that category. I learnt how to lead a class discussion and how to slowly chip away at big ideas. I thoroughly enjoyed this class, it has been one of the most productive of my time at Yale. If Yale teaches you how think, how to learn and how to apply external concepts to your own personal experiences and perspective; then this is absolutely a Yale course. My favourite class in all 4 years here.
New insights into friendship as a sacrament; a passion for learning

This class explored post-war non-religious spirituality -- "the hip" -- as can be found in counterculture movements from the Beats and the Hippies, to the Acid Churchgoers and the Discordians. We learned a how to identify commonalities and distinctions between all these movements. Besides a bunch of knowledge on cultural movements I did not know existed, this class gave me a foundation for studying spirituality, esotericism, fringe reactions, and American identities. Prof. Greer truly cares about helping one grow as a writer, academic, student, etc. This class definitely makes the academic setting inspiring in a way very few classes can.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The only weakness is that it could be longer, the strengths lie in the professors ability to make every student feel valuable, worthy and safe to the point there their best and most original thoughts are given space to present themselves.

Discussed during the course, however I believe incorporating more mixed media sessions would be beneficial. Also, the in person style may be preferable however it was incredibly conducive to my learning style in the virtual setting.

Strengths: Fascinating subject matter you can't get much of anywhere else in the Yale Bluebook; great set of readings; invested and insightful professor; engaging and motivated group of peers
weaknesses:  Hmm, I mean a class on this material is bound to attract people with an annoying alternative edge; also, very late class time

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I am sad that this course was virtual but the connection between professor and student, and between students was strong enough that I almost forgot it was virtual. more engaging than most in person classes I was a part of.

Breaks were very helpful. As was the casual setting and the engaging nature of the professor. Mixed media session helped build some classroom comradery, though this was likely weakened by the pandemic. Weekly response questions/statements helped keep class up-to-date as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I could not recommend this course enough. It was a privilege to spend 2 hours a week with this professor learning about a truly relevant topic in the scope of recent history. Professor Greer is doing important work and every students input feels valuable. This is the best class I have taken in my four years here, I wish I could take it again. Truly 17/10.
Yes, absolutely - best class Ive taken so far.

This class is truly one of the most amazing classes I have taken at Yale--not only is the course material so excellent and niche, Professor Greer is one of the best professors that I have had the honor of meeting at Yale. Professor Greer cultivates a culture of inclusivity and growth during class. I am so thankful for this class and the experiences I have gained and information that will stay with me forever.
YES! This is a must take course.

Definitely. Some of the material is niche -- after all, it includes esoteric spiritualities and cults -- but all of its worth learning about, no matter how weird it may seem at first. I know it took this course because I was interested in Beat and Hippy literature as well as a theorization of counterculture. I definitely got this and more.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class also employed optional Mixed Media sessions which were synchronous.
